it is just 100 years since Ernest
Rutherford in his laboratory at the
University of Manchester announced the
discovery of the nucleus of the atom
in the experiment in his laboratory a
beam of charged particles called alpha
particles that are produced by the
natural radioactivity of radium was
allowed to fall on a very thin gold foil
and to Rutherford's great surprise that
was found that some of these alpha
particles were bouncing backwards and
Rutherford concluded from this that the
alpha particles must be encountering
something inside the gold atom something
very small and very heavy having most of
the mass of the atom and this he
identified as the nucleus of the atom it
was the beginning of modern atomic and
nuclear physics now this was great

what I would call big science
Rutherford's experimental team consisted
of one postdoc named Geiger you may know
the name and an undergraduate and that
was it the he was supported by a grant

than but still 70 pounds the most
expensive part of his experimental setup

bigger the alpha particles these
energetic charged particles from radium
decay didn't have enough energy to

into the nucleus and see what it it's
made of it was necessary to use

this had already started in the 30s with

cosmic rays are extremely energetic
charged particles that strike the Earth

where they would collide with each other

times the square of the speed of light

product the charged particles paths are

you have to reduce the curvature of
